title: Most expensive B Movie of all time
review: What an absolute load of tosh. Pretending to be shot in one take is the only interesting thing about this B Movie.

title: Slow, predictable and kind of boring.
review:
I was looking forward to seeing this but I was so very disappointed. All the major scenes were completely over egged, not in an action packed kind of way but exaggerated to the point that the characters decisions made no sense. From trying to tightrope walk over a bridge in full view of any enemy soldiers for miles around to the ridiculous scene of running across no man's land, it was hard to feel taken by this movie. Indeed its easy to see why the Germans lost this war considering their troops must have been trained to shoot by Star Wars own Stromtroopers plus the main character never had to reload his weapon, Infinite ammo certainly is a big advantage in war.

In fairness to it, the movie looks amazing, but while there is certainly a story there threatening to reveal itself it gets lost behind theatrics.

title: Some visual excellence but overall it is fairly stupid.
review: Story is idiotic. The way the two soldiers go about their business is laughable, no logic at all unless the lads are complete morons. Props are stupid e.g flashlights that exceed anything that existed during that time. Acting is not good so casting gets zero points. There are much more idiotic and infeasible things to this movie but see for yourself, by all means.

title: One of the best movies I have ever seen
review: Words cannot describe how good this movie is. One of the best movies ever made and an incredible achievement in cinema. I genuinly have no idea how they managed to film some of the shots in this movie. Incredible cinematography, acting, music, sound design, set design, characters, story, pacing, immersion, everything is incredible about this movie. If you have the opportunity, go watch this in IMAX, this movie is the best cinema experience I've ever had.

title: Bored
review: Really, i dont understand why this movie have a good rating, I expected more

title: Good film with too many flaws
review:
I enjoyed it and I feel like it had it's heart in the right place but there were too many things that just didn't work.

Pros
  • Their heart was in the right place and they showed a touching story with a good message.


  • They experimented with style (one-shot technique) which hopefully brought more people in to see it.


  • The acting was quite good.


  • It was quite entertaining.


Cons
  • The one-shot technique did not work for me. It felt more like a lets-play of a video game (like Oblivion or Skyrim). There was even a 'game over scene' so to speak and a starting a new level scene. The characters you encounter often felt like NPC with awkward one liners that you just walk away from once their dialogue is done.


  • The characters made too many mistakes that they didn't learn from. They looked like completely green soldiers who kept forgetting that they were in a war and fighting the Germans, as they kept trying to save them! And each time they were shocked that the germans actually wantes to kill them in return...


  • Much like in a game, the germans were completely one dimensional killing machines. Even when being saved their only response was to kill. It felt awkward and unnatural. In real life there might have been more back and forth and more morally grey areas.


  • The main character completed his journey only because he was lucky (and not because of any smart decisions or skill, of which he had none). I highly doubt that the person he is based off was this reckless and stupid.


  • There are too many coincidences: the rat, the plane, the cow, finding the right people at the right time etc. Again it's too much like a video game where you know it will work out and where events happen because you are the main character.


  • Weird plot holes where his important letter and photographs are completely fine even though he spent a long time submerged in water... And where he drinks milk from a dirty bucket that has been there for god knows how long and then offers it to a baby...


  • A missed opportunity to show that this was indeed a 'world' war and was actually quite international with different battalions from different countries. Instead they just did diversity box ticking that made no sense historically.


I am glad this film exists and it is a better war film than many, however, for me, the flaws are too great to give it a higher score. It would have made a better video game than a film in my opinion.

title: Great movie editing, but nothing more to offer here
review:
My expectations for "1917" were not to high since I am not a big fan of war themed movies, although I really enjoyed Dunkirk and Hawksaw Ridge. To put us simple, 1917 is a good movie if you look at it in a technical perspective. The way it was shot is undeniably amazing and it takes some talented crew to get the amazing result, making us believe it was made in one single shot (although we know that's not the case).
Unfortunately there's pretty much it about "1917". The plot is non existent. I am not being sarcastic, there's literally no story here aside from taking one message from point A to point B. That's it. There's an attempt to create some side stories with random characters that just came out of nowhere, but there's no emotional connection with any of them. And I think this is the major s problem with 1917: you don't feel any emotional connection with the characters and because of that I couldn't care less about what happened to the character's.
I honestly believe that if this movie was shot like any other movie, it would be easily forgotten because, like I said before, the story is nothing more than delivering a message. Period. And since the main character is mostly alone, you don't see any dialogue, any way for you to connect.
As much respect that I have for all the crew involved in this project, I must admit that it didn't work for me.

title: Long and drawn out
review: Not the best war film I've seen, not a lot acutally happens, the wrong main character dies. Around average and totally over rated

title: Boring, Boring, Boring
review: This was as Boring with virtually no battle scenes as Dunkirk. I take it back, Dunkirk had more action. Hollyweird can't do a good war film anymore. Always an overload of unnecessary drama.

title: Story was lacking. Visual masterpiece
review:
I've seen some reviews say this is the greatest war movie ever and that baffles me. The story was very predictable & left little to the imagination. Cinematography is amazing though & was very well shot.

Also not sure why it was rated R. PG-13 would have been better in my opinion.

title: Good direction, bad pacing
review: While the direction, editing and sound design is top notch, the pacing really hurt this film. There are many moments where I sat there bored because a scene would go on for too long. And because the characters are not that interesting, I can't immerse myself into the movie. Would still reccomend seeing it for the direction and cinematography, though, because it is amazing.

title: Painful movie to watch
review: Not sure what all the fuss is about this movie, but giving it a 1 star is very generous. Waste of time and money. I was expecting a 'saving private Ryan' type movie, but was very disappointed.

title: Entertaining
review:
This is no Saving Private Ryan, but the story was good. The filmography was excellent.
There are a few flaws though like how the main character blabs to almost everyone he meets the details of his mission though he should have known the consequences if that information was leaked to the enemy. Also, the German snipers and soldiers were such terrible shots they never hit their target, the main character.

The whole film consists of two super long lenses. But the long lens of this film is not used to show off skills, but to make you unable to escape from the most personal senses, unable to watch, unable to choose the grand perspective of history, unable to treat everyone in the film as the statistical data in the war. So a unique technique with a unique narrative way is excellent.

title: How can someone be so creative?
review: What a beautiful movie. The cinematography, music, and acting was just unbelievable. What an incredibly touching movie, you feel like you are right there with the main characters the entire movie and you want them to make it so bad!

During the climax, my whole body muscle was locked in the theater seat, and the lacrimal gland began to collapse involuntarily. This movie represents the purest audition shock, the most extreme play of the movie language, and my back was completely wet when the subtitle was released.

title: Giving this movie a mediocre review is a crime.
review: Sam Mendes again, creates an amazing piece of work. Brilliantly executed. The cinematography is jaw dropping. A stunning work of art. Made to look like one seamless single shot, it is amazingly well done. Highly recommended.

title: All style, weak story.
review: The cinematography is one of the best I've ever seen, action is great, but story is full of plot holes. For example: trap bomb exploded near the characters yet they survived without scratches. Or the scene there one of them got stabbed and the place got full of comrades out of nowhere. Whole movie is full of inconsistencies and plot holes.

title: It's over rated
review:
First solder dies, the second solder delivers the message. There are some chasing scene and good cinematography, just it. The movie is not realistic. Perhaps teenagers like it.

I am so sorry for Hollywood.

title: On par with Ryan and maybe better!
review: The attention to detail and realism in this movie is what makes it so good and believable. For instance, I don't know how they pulled off certain character's not breathing after they die. Sure they can hold their breath, but considering one "dead" actor remains on the screen for a good minute or more makes that unlikely. Anyhow - awesome movie and highly recommended! It's not your typical action-packed war flick, and that's actually refreshing, but it is indeed suspenseful!

title: A Masterpiece
review: I am not someone who loves war movies, but I love and appreciate superior film making and if you do too, 1917 is a must see. Even if you are put off by the first world war theme, just on a cinematic level this is a must see. The cinematography is incredible , the acting is top notch, George Mackay was robbed for not being nominated for an Oscar , the story will have you engrossed and on the edge of your seat. I have to add, this movie proves how out of touch Hollywood is with what deserves an Oscar and how PC kills everything. Having seen 5 of the nominees , including the garbage Parasite, 1917 deserved Best Picture. This movie is a the only film nominated that is genuinely a masterpiece. Who will even remember Parasite in a few years ?

title: One of the best movies ever
review:
This movie I wish I'd seen on the big screen, it was amazing cinematography and one of the best films I've ever seen. It's thrilling from start to end, and yet so touching in so many moments.
The story line is subtle, but the sense of honor that our soldiers displayed in our wars is something the script captured. It's not the heroic version, it's the deep core value that men have sacrificed for our freedom. And a needed message too during our current pandemic, wartime sacrifices and support of others. I felt so much hope. Bravo to all who made this film!

title: Visually fantastic, not soo much storyline depth though.
review:
Visually it's absolutely stunning, and the one take is well done (though certainly not perfect).

Ultimately though the storyline just doesn't have that much substance, George MacKay as the lead role was poorly chosen and Mendes just had to add pc nonsense that sadly simply wasn't the reality of 1917 Europe.

Cameos were fantastically picked though.

title: Slow and Boring
review: The title says it all, don't waste your time on this one. I found myself bored since the first minute of the movie. I didn't care much about any of the characters, they were uninteresting and monotone throughout. The writing was terrible that I did not care of what was happening at all. The camera work was amazing but that's about it. The one shot was clever contributed to how slow this movie was. Overall, a forgettable Oscar bait movie.

title: It's like Lord of the Rings on ketamine with no Dwarfs.
review:
The movie has a strong start visually, then gets all Elijah Woods- pale white guys staggering through scenery on a seemingly impossible mission, trading wooden dialogue.
It also reminded me of Dicaprio in 'The Revenant', where a white guy staggers through scenery and an implausible story, stuck together by an implausible plot.
Best not to see it in the cinema so you can play with your phone and make it through the two hours having done something useful.

title: Technicaly impressive but otherwise laughable.
review:
The faux single shot gimmick was technically impressive but that's all this film has going for it, the rest is laughably bad.

Our protagonist lurches from one ludicrous situation to another while German soldiers do all they can to rival Star Wars Stormtroopers as the worst shots in cinematic history. There are only so many contrived coincidences and inexplicably missed shots you can take before suspending your disbelief becomes impossible and all you can do is laugh.

Let's not beat about the bush here, this film is appalingly written, relying almost wholly on utterly unrealistic situations, preposterous coincidences, plot armour, cliches and cheap sentiment and should have been laughed out of cinemas, but apparently a bit of technical wizardy is all it takes these days to be declared a masterpiece.

title: Realistic war movie
review:
This movie radiates some kind of nihilistic atmosphere that enforces the characters and story. The movie is brilliant in its simplicity. It's dark and gritty and luckily different than the usual Hollywood brainless blockbuster.

If you like war movies: a must see.

title: Exciting
review:
A good movie, with good filming.
I can't forget it.

title: Wow
review: Wow, just wow, amazing, stunning, thrilling.... just wow ...: the sound and the music, just wow

title: Incredibly well made war drama.
review:
Well, this was a very different war movie! Much of the film works only because of the stunning camera work and cinematography, and great acting by Dean-Charles Chapman. The film has a great production design and hauntingly beautiful score. It is also visually stunning. There's a scene where he wanders through the ruins of a city, being lit only by bombs going off in the distance - and it is an absolutely beautiful, mesmerizing scene. '1917' is filled with spectacular scenes.

This is one of those rare movies I can't really fault in any way, although it probably won't go down as one of my favorite films. Every scene was done to perfection and the film flows effortlessly and beautifully. I only have praise for this film. '1917' is a moving drama about friendship, loyalty and determination against all odds.

title: I was mesmerised!
review:
This film is a breakthrough in terms of the production values. Its cinematography was astonishing. I felt like I'm there with the characters and feeling all of those activities that were happening.

It is still unbelievable for me to understand how they could handle those scenes, sequences and edits!

There was a lot of minute details that they take care of like a master. Don't even doubt that you are watching a masterpiece, a 21st century beauty, a gift from cinema, a great tribute to the victims, a great tribute to the humanity, dignity, morality...

Sam Mendes, Roger Deakins and Lee Smith immortalise themselves with this masterpiece.

I was in a very emotional state during and after watching this film. Actually the amount of work that I know they put on to this film was overwhelming and fantastic.

There are some sequences that you will not forget ever in your life.

George MacKay and Dean-Charles Chapman did a great job and the rest of the cast were amazing also. Thomas Newman was very good and helped to build the emotional state of the scenes.

I think the only weak points about this film were toning down war and depicts it as "soldiers-life-matters-first" and a bit predictability of the screenplay.

9/10

title: Another competent but unoriginal anti-war movie
review: You need to watch Gallipoli (1981) first to appreciate how incredibly BETTER the Mel Gibson flick was than this one. Under the guise of a drama Sam Mendes has actually concocted a lecture. I understand why film-buffs have marked this one up - because of the complete lack of other good movies. I did not appreciate all the "wokemon" stuff. For me it marred what could have been a regular, good war movie.

title: An Experience
review:
A great movie will leave you with a feeling, an experience, a moment on screen that's etched deep in your memory and stays with you forever. A scene or two where your heart rate rapidly increases or tears feel up your eyes. A score that matches perfectly with what is being portrayed on screen.

In Lord of the Rings, it's the 'Wolves of Isengard' scene.

In Fight Club, it's the final explosion scene.

In 300, it's the slow motion fight scenes.

In Godfather, it's the final shot.

In The Dark Knight, it's the voice over of Gordon while Batman is making a run for it.

In The Matrix, it's the 'he is the one' scene.

In Braveheart, it's the 'Freedom' shout scene.

In Joker, it's the scene where he is cheered by the mob and he gives a bloody smile.

In Private Ryan, it's the final battle scenes where the heroes make their last stand.

In Kingdom of Heaven, it's the 'surrendering of Jerusalem' scene.

In Terminator 2, it's the 'robot self terminate' scene.

In Drive, it's the final scene.

1917 is a great movie. Enough said.
It's the first movie i watched in cinema in 2020 and i loved it,it was great

title: Slowest War Movie Ever- Yawn
review: Very slow moving movie, I love war movies but this was actually quite boring. A lot of the scenes feel very long and drawn out. I was fairly disappointed and found myself fighting the urge to turn it off. Yes, the ending was kind of cool. But it definitely wasn't worth sitting through the rest of the boring movie.

title: BEST FILM I'VE SEEN IN AGES!
review: I think I recommended just about everyone I see to watch this film. It's well made, EXCEPTIONAL acting, gives you an insight into just exactly our soldiers went through. I think that every single person should watch this film just so they can appreciate our men and history. I don't know how the film makers did it but you ACTUALLY feel like you're there in the film with them. Loved, loved loved it!

title: The 'Saving Private Ryan' of WW1
review:
Being one of the nine Best Picture nominees for the annual Oscars, '1917' emerged as one of the finest movies of 2019 and one of the favorites to claim the most coveted prize in the film industry. Though the South Korean comedy drama 'Parasite' swept the big categories, leaving '1917' solely with awards for cinematography, sound and special effects, the movie still has become both a commercial hit and critically acclaimed worldwide.

The story is set in WW1 era France, and follows (more or less literally) the footsteps of two British soldiers handed the task of impending an entire company from walking into a trap set up by the Germans, by delivering an order of retreat to the commander of the company. In order to complete their mission they need to cross muddy fields abundant of rotting corpses and their stench, make their way through mined bunkers and avoid Germans in towns devastated by war. Will they manage to deliver the message in time?

The most immediate and flagrant distinction in the movie is the widely talked-about one-shot technique, meaning that the film is devised in such a way that it looks like the whole affair I shot in one long, fluid take. It is a great device for sustaining the tension in each scene, for instance in the opening scene in the British trenches, where the claustrophobia gradually increases until it's time for our soldiers to set out on their journey. When they finally enter the barren, reeking battlefield the viewer has transformed into a third soldier, feeling the unease with every passing plane and flinching at the sight of the dissolving corpses. The meticulous cinematography is nothing short of an immaculate masterwork, giving the landscapes a bleak, gritty and desolate look, suitable for this kind of war movie. Overall the movie is technically impeccable, both looking and sounding astonishing.

Despite its many benefits, ultimately the film's most unique feature remains its greatest obstacle: the fluidity of the camera movement prevents a more elaborate look into the characters and a more emotional connection with them (notwithstanding the poignancy of the subject of war alone), leaving the film rather hollow on an emotional level, something the good acting can't redeem.

Acting as the WW1 equivalent to Spielberg's 'Saving Private Ryan', '1917' shares many of the latter's greatest attributes; being a realistic, non-glorifying and morbid depiction of war. Among all WW2 movies it's also refreshing to see a film taking place in the less exploited First World War. All in all '1917' is further evidence that the film industry after a few years off truly is on its way back.

title: Complaint
review:
What is your reason for showing the Germans wild?
They are very good guys. Please make the movie logical

title: boring
review: Unlikable characters with aimless dignity that was not sold by it's story or actors.

title: Worst war movie in decades
review:
Plain, pale, plot hole-ridden, incredibly overrated. No doubt the cinematography is good, but the story is soulless.

O how I miss the time of Saving Private Ryan!

title: 1917 is nothing more than just another movie...
review: NEWSFLASH!! 1917 is nothing more than just another movie. It's an amalgam of the marathon legend born from the Ancient Greeks' battle against the Persians - and a script born from a 12-year-old boy's daydreaming fantasy of being a hero by defying all odds. It's all wrapped up into a format akin to a non-interactive video game. It's a 6/10 from me, and I'm being quite generous at that!!

title: Entertaining and stunning. But not flawless.
review:
There has been set a lot about the cinematographic grandeur of this movie. Though nevertheless, 1917 could not really 'capture' me. Let me explain to you wihy, without going into details too much:

The movie to me felt like The Lord of the Rings: An unlikely hero goes with a friend on a quest to bring something valuable into the dark lands. A lot of the praised cinematics of this movie remind me a lot of Lotr as well. The wasteland, the forest with the chanting, the firelands and also Blake dying struck me a lot like Frodo (almost) dying.

Unlike Lotr there wasn't really a side story though. Going from point a to point b was kind of it. And it would not have been that hard if it were not for some highely unlikely events. Using the first World War as a scenery also felt somewhat random to me; there was hardly any context concerning the war. Germans are evil and shoot like stormtroopers, but didn't get any human charectaristics. This movie could have also been situated in the American Civil War or the Cold War near the Berlin wall; kind of everywhere where the protagonist has to beyond enemy lines without modern technology.

I do wonder what happened to the hero since he stuck his open wound hand in a dead man's body which would seem like a fatal infection waiting to happen back then.

title: Saving Private Ryan - WWI Edition
review:
6 stars for the setting, and the cinematography 0 stars for the story and acting

Story Germans left their trenches, British phone lines cut, 2 soldiers have to deliver a message behind enemy lines. We have seen this in Saving Private Ryan, only difference here: The soldiers know where the recipient of the message is located. On their way they see friendly aircraft, at least 2 times flying over them. My question: Why didn't the aircraft drop these messages? Story would be over.

Acting: While George MacKay delivered an okay-ish performance, Dean-Charles Chapman was ridiculous. He is just too immature for this role.. his character came over like a baby.. I didn't buy it and in my eyes it was pretty unauthentic.

It is good for a watch, I just wonder why they picked this poor story, (which we already saw in Saving Private Ryan) for this beautifully shot film.

title: Unbelievable. Or rather hard to believe.
review:
This movie is very well shot, but the exaltation ends when the rat triggers the trap. The explosion leaves the two soldiers unharmed, but is still is strong enough to collapse the large shelter and underground tunnel, built to withstand heavy artillery fire for hours and days?
And it's downhill from there. The whole movie is like a shooter game where the protagonist is stumbling from one fight to the next. Except that computer games do a better job of connecting the little adventures. The lowlights have been mentioned too often already: Cow, milk, plane, pilot, dead buddy, but at least we got milk for a sidequest. Brits appear and disappear. Countersniping the worst sniper ever. Enemy soldier rushing. Mother with a baby, and she needs "lait"! YES, 150XP.
Enough already,

title: Good not Great
review:
1917 captured the beauty of the French landscape and showed how war could transform beauty into a snarl of death, ugliness and destruction.

Special effects, editing and costumes were well done yet acting lacked a certain degree of engagement and I had the experience I'd been watching actors instead of people, especially the Germans who had virtually no depth whatsoever, generically depicted as being stupid, evil and incompetent.

Other reviewers had compared 1917 to WW1's answer to Saving Private Ryan. Nothing could be further from the truth. Saving Private Ryan portrayed depth of story, multifaceted characters, nuance and humor, and it was a film that operated simultaneously on multiple levels, whereas 1917 possessed none of these qualities. With war movies like Ryan, Deer Hunter and Apocalypse Now I left the theater jolted into an altered state; the savagery of war left left me with a gaping hole and it required time to heal. WIth 1917 the echo of war ceased when the projector switched off.

title: One shot take masterclass but not much action and no story
review:
The film is a technical marvel as it's entirely shot in one take similar to Birdman but doing a one shot take in such a vast open battlefield complete with the river jump sequence is a new level of one take wizardry. The story follows two soldiers in WWI who must deliver a message to a battalion on the front line to cancel the attack as it's a trap. That's pretty much the story as the film is more of a visual experience told from a first person perspective of the journey to deliver the message. It's similar to Dunkirk where there isn't much story. The problem is vast chunks of time is spent just watching the soldiers walking around and observing the war torn landscape which is hauntingly beautiful. Only halfway through the movie do we get our first sniper shootout which lasts a couple minutes. Then it's back to walking around and running. That's the entire essence of the movie. The soldier uses his rifle in the sniper shootout scene and briefly in one earlier scene but that's the extent of the gunfights. In comparison, Saving Private Ryan and Fury were far more action packed, brutal and entertaining. Of course 1917 is meant to be a visual first person point of view experience and succeeds on that front but I can't help but think the one take technique is mostly a gimmick. I think the film might be better with more takes rather than entirely shot in one take as this allows more perspectives, more depth to the story and allows for time jumps so it's not constrained by the real time limitations of one take. The one take technique can add an immersive experience when used in certain scenes like a frontline battle but I'm not sure it's as effective when used for the entirety of a movie. Overall I enjoyed the film but I would have liked more story and more action. I found the ending somewhat anticlimactic and unsatisfying.

I saw 1917 after seeing Parasite which won best picture and director. And I only saw them both after the Oscars. I avoided Parasite because I do not enjoy reading subtitles. But after winning best picture I saw Parasite and enjoyed it but did not think it was that great to deserve best picture and director as I likened it to a clever twist on the home invasion genre with an allegory of class conflict. But now that I've seen 1917 which was the frontrunner to win best picture and director I can appreciate why the academy voted for Parasite. 1917 is a great sensory experience but story wise is hollow. Also there isn't much action so nearly the entire runtime is just watching the soldiers walking around and running and that's it. If more story and battle scenes were added it could've been so much more entertaining. Best picture is relative and subjective. At first I didn't think Parasite deserved best picture but now that I've seen 1917 I do think Parasite is the better choice. Parasite has a simple but rich story with great characters and characterization with a clever twist and a strangely sad but satisfying conclusion that's believable. Not to take anything away from 1917 as it's a huge technical achievement. Both are good films but Parasite is far more memorable and stays with you after the movie ends.

title: One of the best
review: I have never been to war, but experienced my share of life-threatening situations, including facing the wrong end of a gun. Watching this movie almost felt like the real deal, it let me glimpse the human condition in war. Ruthless reality coming at you too fast to allow pondering on your emotions, having to tuck it all away in order to stay alert, in order not to die. The randomness of who gets to live and who doesn't. One second your companion stands beside you, the next he is dying, and then on. Trying to focus on what is relevant in the now and here, and not losing focus on where you need to go. The actors deliver a brilliant performance in conveying this struggle convincingly. Additionally, brilliant screenplay and cinematography. One of the best movies I have ever watched.

title: It's really good
review: A story isn't told exclusively by dialogue, this movie proves us that, trough amazing visuals we are told not only the adventure of being inside the war but also we live the struggle as if we were in there.

title: One of the Greatest War Drama Movie.
review:
When i was watching it I felt like i was watching the Greatest Movie Ever Made in World Cinema History.
Performance, vfx, score, direction, camera moment everything was great and the cinematography was like hell. One of the best war drama movie ever made and the best movie on World War I.

title: See it to feel it.
review: Just outstanding. Brillant performance. Sam and the boys have nailed it. There is so much to take away from such a awasome performance.

title: One of the most tense movies I have ever seen
review: 1917 is perhaps the best example of a movie that I can think of where it actually feels like a war experience and as if you are there with these two soldiers. It's a movie that expertly builds up tension throughout by using silence, music, and the awesome direction by Sam Mendes. It also amazes me how I felt like anything could happen at any moment during the film, which really kept me on edge during almost the entire runtime. It's also a movie that can really capture the desperate situation soldiers faced during the World War and how beautiful the little things in life can be, especially when faced with all of this darkness. Things like a baby or leaves falling off a beautiful tree. It's almost like a horror movie in the sense that you are waiting for a "jump scare" of sorts throughout the entire runtime. Some people have criticized the lack of characterization, but I would disagree. I believe we get just enough information to be invested in the success of this particular mission, and enough to care about the lives of the people we follow. I loved this movie and I really don't have anything bad to say about it.

title: Greatest war film ever!
review: Twenty minutes into the film you will be gripped, by the end of this film you will realise you have just watched the greatest war film ever made, Sam mendes has created a real masterpiece.

title: BEST movie I have ever seen!
review: I saw it twice within a week and could watch it again, no problem. It is the most intense, riveting movie I have ever witnessed. Truly an awesome (a much overused word, but appropriate here) cinematic accomplishment!

title: *1917* - (Review Number 1,679) . Title : "In These Last 5 Hours"
review:
L left my home around 12 pm today , to head ti the theater where this was playing. I'd been wanting to see it since it was released but was always sidetracked by something going on in my life.I arrived there before 1:00 and the movie started at 1:02.

I'm sure as most here may have felt before it began ... I had NO idea what to expect or what I was going to see. I've seen many a war movie in my life , from the black and white era to Saving Private Ryan and Fury in 2014. .....but (and I am not exaggerating) , this film has captured exactly every feeling, emotion, action of those made to fight in the truly nightmarish and holocaust like places that are the front lines and battlefields.

They have also fully captured the look of everything a military set up and used in this , World War 1 and future wars. The look is sad, scary,somber and in some cases as dark as war truly is. (Not speaking from any experience but I know this movie does not lie). The cinematography, yes, does pull that off perfectly , in my opinion.

As some already know the story is , two British soldiers are chosen to get a message to another regiment many miles across 'no man's land' ( where if the enemy spots you , you are likely to get shot and killed). The reason is, the Germans have retreated but it may be a trick. So they have to get there to warn them and find the brother of the younger soldier.

From the start, the bulk of the first half is filmed in 'real time'. following every move of these 2. Without giving anything away, there's a slight pause of darkness, then the real time pursuit continues. I was astounded at how steadily and perfectly the camera (cameras?) followed along.

Lastly, in an early morning scene in a village, the true look of war/night time battle is (once again) shown by (I can only call it astounding) visuals and cinematography. Usually a few hours after a film, I've forgotten most of what I've seen. In this case ....even if I never watched this film again (and I will) there is no way I will ever forget any of this.

Much like those who survives wars , they never forget either. World War 1 , for a long time after 1930's "All Quiet On The Western Front" , was very forgotten and thought by younger generations as 'not a serious war'. This movie , like Western Front, shows that is not the case. At 3:01 , my odyssey was over.

It was was just as violent and horrific as World War 2 or any war since then. I will not make any Oscar predictions here. Except to say , I'd be very pleased to see it placed among the the top pictures of the past.

Please , go see this ...I put no spoilers in here because ,feel , it is not boring and it's certainly something you will ever forget. Not everyone will feel the same but well, I can only recommend.

title: Don't believe the ratings
review:
A visually and technically impressive, gripping until a certain point but then the holes in the implausible storyline weaken the overall impact, to the point where it feels unsatisfying and not engaging any longer.

Instead watch Elem Klimov's 'Come and See', a visionary cry of despair from the depths of hell -as a reviewer wrote-, and rewatch Coppola's epic masterpiece 'Apocalypse Now'

title: Worth watching not legendary
review: This is a good film, there are some marvellous scenes depicting the horrors of war but there was not enough action involved for my liking, I get its trying to show you that they're all afraid young blokes but they could have thrown in some extra firefights or explosions just to bring the audience further into it. The ending was a bit of an anti climax aswell. watchable but needed some extra touches to be right up there, wish it had been

title: Beautiful but far from perfect
review:
The movie is technically perfect. Beautiful shots (not, it's not a single shot) all over the place and one of the best cinematography works I've ever seen.

However, it lacks passion, good characters and a more compelling story. The first 30 minutes are really boring and, even if it gets much better after that, you never really care about the characters.

It's good enough because it looks great and you always want to see what will be the next beautiful shot. Watch it like an episode of Planet Earth, however don't expect a cinema masterpiece.

title: The Reeeee-losers hate reality
review:
This movie doesn't have unicorns and it doesn't have wahmen, must scream at the sky instead of enjoying this masterclass of cinema. Compelling story, characters, and filmmaking; you know, just the real things take make a good movie.
Go watch a good film, hopefully the low iq generation of scream at the sky social justice losers fade away into obscurity.

title: An impressive film
review:
It's beautifully made and has just enough action to keep tensions high and tug at the heartstrings, intimately depicting the human cost of war. I got emotional a few times.

I do caution that as a War movie, it's more of a drama than an action film. Sure there's action and suspense, and some thrills, but this isn't Saving Private Ryan or Dunkirk from a visceral standpoint. It's smaller in both scale and scope.

1917 follows a couple of soldiers as they journey to the front line carrying information which could save over a thousand of their fellows soldiers' lives... if they get there in time.

It's in the aforementioned scale and scope where 1917 falls short of being great. The main plot of the movie suffered for not being big enough or feeling important enough. There's no storming of the beaches at Normandy. No rousing Winston Churchill speech at the end. The film doesn't connect the events it depicts into their greater significance in the war. Again, it felt small scale and narrow in scope.

But to reiterate, I very much liked it. It's a lovely film filled with tension and emotion, think Kubrick's Paths of Glory without the 10/10 ending. Great work by all involved: Director Sam Mendes, Composer Thomas Newman, the whole cast and crew.

One of the years best films, probably at the bottom of my top ten.

title: Great Film!
review: It's been a while since I've watched a war movie that I have just loved from start to finish! This one is truly great!

title: Absolutely incredible
review: Give this a watch and see the beauty of it for yourself, because this is a movie where you truly are left speechless after.

title: Touching and Tragic Story
review: This is a tale of a Soldiers struggle to keep a promise. It is a visual masterpiece but it lacks in believability. As a Soldier parts of the tale did not make any sense but I take it with a grain of salt as it is based in World War 1. It delivers action and suspense while draped in the hellish emotions of a world falling apart around our protagonist. If you didn't catch in on the big screen, it's worth the rental or watching it on TV.

title: There was a lot of hype surrounding this film on release, and it lives up to those expectations.
review: There is no doubt this is a very good movie. I will say something about the movie that may give something away about it, so don't read past here until you see the movie. I thought the movie there would be more fighting shown. We don't see even 1 German soldier in the film! some shooting from snipers, a downed German pilot and that was it. Most of the movie shows the young man going across the countryside , and eventually at night. Big fires all around a few people come after him and he falls into a river and is carried almost to where he needs to be. He walks up to them and knows they are who is looking for. The trenches you see and the soldiers are so real and you see a little action, but then the movie is over. So this is NOT a movie about COMBAT. Not at all. if you watch it thinking this is what you will see, you will be sadly disappointed. But otherwise the point of the movie is showing the effort that is made to stop this attack. The filming was excellent. The actors were excellent. I just wished to see some combat.

It's not appropriate for such a cruel film to say that it makes people feel beautiful, but there are several scenes that really make people forget the environment, cherry blossom falling, singing in the forest, running across the charge line, and the last swaying of the grass sea. These are the beauty itself without the background.

Only the first batch of audiences are happy, or the whole movie will not stop thinking about seats and editing points. This one mirror is not so dazzling in the end. It emphasizes real-time sense and on-site sense. The scene after fainting suddenly became magical.

The effect of the film is really shocking and good-looking. There are not only modern props set technology to reproduce the great nihility of the battlefield, but also a sense of individual despair brought by the mirror. In the night, the hero escapes to the extreme. But it's really that there are not enough British actors. They are familiar with each other when they come out, and they are a little bit of a dancer.

Immersive viewing experience, let people quickly into the play. Because of the continuous and large range of lens movement, some places make people a little 3D dizzy. There is almost no trace in the whole mirror, and you will not notice it. Put the fate of the two soldiers in the background of the war, there are not many lines, not only the cruelty of the war, but also the delicate feelings.

It should be said that the long shot saved the film with little plot. Although the whole process marveled at the superb technology, but emotion, human design, theme, conflict are all empty, see the end only feel the technology and the play put the cart before the horse.

The whole film consists of two super long lenses. But the long lens of this film is not used to show off skills, but to make you unable to escape from the most personal senses, unable to watch, unable to choose the grand perspective of history, unable to treat everyone in the film as the statistical data in the war. So a unique technique with a unique narrative way is excellent.

The director's long shot scheduling is also a skill maniac for the audio-visual skills. The long shot with complex motion track is coordinated with the actors to complete the scheduling. This is the legendary audio-visual feast. The rhythm of the story is perfectly controlled, and the long shot scheduling of several plays is very shocking! Two awards of best director and best photography should be stable. In the early years, the shooting technology may not reach such difficulty. The best film should also be this movie.

title: Very Good
review:
I enjoyed this movie very much. Its gritty, charming, sad, Inspiring, thought provoking, gut wrenching, and triumphant.
Sometimes when a movie gets down to the "meat & potatos" of action/suspense, it tends to either sacrifice character build or go on for hours. This is not the case with this movie.
I'll admit there were a few parts where I scratched me head; trying to figure out what the lead character was doing...but overall it was a Rollercoaster of emotions.
I was entertained from start to finish; & satisfied with majority of my questions answered.
I didn't feel like the filming was theatrical. But rather felt that certain liberties taken, were entirely plausible.
But be prepared to cringe, scream in frustration, cry from sorrow AND happiness.and don't be surprised if, at the end of the movie, you find you just need to sit in silence and compartmentalize everything you just watched.

title: How this film never won best Picture, I'll never know.
review: I always knew it would Win best Cinematography at the Oscars. But, Come On! Not winning best Picture or Original Screenplay is just Mystifying. And it should've Won best Director, as well. This film is a work of Art. And the Poetry about it is Mesmerising. Some things in life Baffle me, and 1917 not cleaning up at the Oscars is one of them.

title: A true story about bravery
review:
The masterpiece '1917' is an intense co-production that presents us World War I, on 6 april 1917, on the endless battlefields of France, when Corporals Schofield and Blake are requested to complete a mission, to inform Colonel McKenzie, in charge of the Second Division, about a German military strategy that puts in danger the life of 1600 soldiers.
Passing among other soldiers, Schofield and Blake read letters from home and try to encourage themselves.
In trenches they notice something isn't alright, one of the soldiers telling them that General Erinmore wants to talk to them.
They enter fearfully the settlement and soon discover that Lieutenant Joseph, Blake's brother is alive in the Second Division and that Colonel McKenzie thinks that the enemy is retiring. Even so the aerial photos indicate that the next morning McKenzie's attack will be crushed. Schofield and Blake get the order to go to the Second Division, with a letter that contains an order to cancel the attack.
Begins the journey of the two Corporals, in this way building fastly the tension of the movie.
The endless trenches represent a way to salvation of hundred of soldiers, a way full of dangers and uncertainty.
On the road, Schofield begins to doubt about this journey and about himself, the doubt being like a sign of an ill omen.
Blake doesn't hesitate at all and is determined to save his brother, even when he sees other injured soldiers.
When they enter on enemy's territory, the suspense increases even more.
The backgrounds with human and horse corpses, razor wire, mosquitoes, mud, rats, gray skies and the profound Oscar-winning Sound Mixing design a visceral, vivid, post-apocalyptic and extremely tensed vision.
The Corporals are frightened by two aircrafts passing by, that prove to be allied.
On the front line, they notice that the enemy has left, but is not far.
Later, they enter underground, remaining rather surprised when they see the abandoned army post. They find a grenade which explodes, but succeed to go out.
Being wounded, Schofield regrets the journey. Even if Blake tells him that he can return, he doesn't give up.
Marching on the field, Blake explains the importance of the medal that Schofield gave away for a bottle of wine.
The scene at the abandoned farm is desolate, the cherry trees being severed. Still, being in bloom, denotes an image of hope.
Over the barn collapses an enemy aircraft putting the life of the Corporals at risk. They try to help the pilot, which stabs Blake, and Schofield shoots the pilot.
Blake dies and his last wish is his partner of voyage to find his brother.
The entire movie is shoot in one spectacular frame, a remarkable achievement in cinema.
Schofield gets the advice to not think too much at bad things. He is carryed with a truck until a collapsed bridge.
From this point the suspense is mastefully portrayed.
The nocturnal surreal imagery of the town in ruins has impressed me the most, alongside the sound editing, the scene being hallucinatory, from another era.
The fire is destructing, but like death, it could be a new beginning.
Schofield succeed to go out from the city full of enemies and jumps into the river. He reaches the Second Division.
Despite the fact that the attack has begun, the Corporal enters with bravery on the battlefield to arrive faster to McKenzie.
Making his way though soldiers, Schofield arrives at the Colonel in a race against the clock.
He succeeds to save the life of hundreds of soldiers.
Then he finds Lieutenant Blake and tells him about his brother.
The scene at the end shows Schofield looking with reconciliation at the picture of his wife.
All the 119 minutes of the movie made a good impression on me through the technical quality, backgrounds and mistery.

title: One of the best World War 1 movies, with great cinematography by Roger Deakins
review: Great movie!! A very long and impossible mission for a rookie soldier with no experience. Unbelievable obstacles along the way, pretty intense. Hghly recommended!!

title: Fantastic Cinematography & Historical Accuracy!
review: 1917 is a prime example of a well produced and accurate historical film which gives the audience a real glimpse into the perspective of a solider(s) in World War I ! This entire film in my opinion has very purposeful elements throughout it. First off, the feel of the single shot videography was great! The editing was top notch and I even had to question myself wether or not it there were cuts in the photography or no at times, fantastic! Second, this movie had a great attitude awareness! The violence and actions were purposeful and weren't for the sake of themselves, but rather an accurate presentation of the sequences and events that occurred. You can real see the directors intention of the film clearly. Overall, 1917 was a fantastic film which I will be watching again very soon!

title: cinematic masterpiece.
review:
Stunning, everything, Music, directions, cinematography , performance ......

the movie is also ONE SHOT , like there is no transition, which more stunning.

the movie should n must watch on BIG screen and bad ass speakers.

title: INCREDIBLE
review:
What a movie!!! I truly haven't seen a movie like this in a ling time. The setting, the acting and the directing are marvelous. You'll just flow with the, you' movie as the movie progresses. Then, you'll feel attached to the characters.......an attachment that'll take you to the climax and you'd lay hoping that the movie would never end.

Mind Blowing cinematography!!! You won't forget it. A 10/10.

title: Piece of art
review: I usually don't write reviews but I simply had to with this one. If you haven't seen it, please don't miss out. It's one of the best movies I've seen so far this year. It's brilliant and a piece of art! Really great acting and the screen work and directing is amazing. To film the movie in one shot, I couldn't sit still. So trilling, raw, heartfelt and enticing. Deserve every Oscar they get!

title: a truly immersive experience
review: Operation Alberich is underway, and British aerial recon observes that the Imperial German Army has seemingly pulled back from their position on the Western Front. Knowing this to be a strategic withdrawal instead of a full-fledged retreat, two young enlisted men are tasked with a perilous mission to cross no man's land, go deep behind enemy lines, then deliver a crucial order to the Devonshire Regiment that will prevent a massacre. If director Sam Mendes wanted to pull viewers into the trenches of the first Great War then he succeeded with flying colors: amazing cinematography, stunning visual effects, and masterful direction with the use of long takes make you feel like you're right in the heart of it, and the realism (and sheer horror) of the battle scenes are overwhelming. A fantastic technical achievement, but startling and emotional as well, with characters you can accompany throughout the entire ordeal. ***Â½

title: Stunning
review: A true masterpiece in filmmaking. There really is no need to go in more detail. Parasite is well deserved of all the praise, but I truly think this film should've won.

title: Well, this distracting full-length shot
review: Admittedly, I have never seen such a poetic war movie. For example, although full-length shooting may break the connection of certain scenes, and I can't help but think of the way to shoot the shot, the director also played a lot of new tricks in this way. In terms of scene scheduling, this is perfect and amazing. Switching different perspectives can move the viewer's sight. In a way, it completes the space Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk wants to explore. The plot is not particularly outstanding, so the technology must be excellent. I still like this movie.

title: Great movie
review: Awesome movie portraying the true brutality of ww1. Must watch!!!!

title: great
review: Awakening from the field is filled with small yellow flowers on the grassland to slowly sit down finally can breathe a sigh of relief cows gradually smaller houses there forever friends under the river drift to cherry blossoms night fire abandoned town only from gunfire and silhouette feel crow on the enemy even body is the first time feel so poetic description of delicate and very grand

title: A movie that makes you live, moment by moment
review:
Since the movie was announced, it was clear that it is a film that has its place in cinematic artifacts, especially with the announcement of the starring team, And with the appearance of the first trailer, it was well confirmed, Film 1917 makes you live through the events and feel what the soldier feels from start to finish, Also, the performance of all actors, especially George MacKay Who deserves an Oscar nomination. But the most important thing remains the direct and indiscriminate directing of the method of filming that would otherwise have been an ordinary film in my view It suffices to name the director Sam Mendes. What is wrong with the movie is that it is a little slow, as if you feel that there is no struggle with time.
1917 is a masterpiece.

title: Weep tears that don't let us hate-when Schofield was sitting in the truck compartment
review: Finally, in 2019, weep tears that don't let us hate-when Schofield was sitting in the truck compartment, surrounded by other brothers, he looked at the distant village from the god, which is almost the most heartbreaking in 2019 It's time.

title: Pleasant View for the Eyes
review:
Film has won the best cinematography award in Oscars 2020. I would also unanimously agree on that as it is a real treat for the eyes. Camera work , Angles , Colors and Scenes are really top notch. Change of one scene to another was perfectly handled without becoming a harassment to the viewer's eyes. Most of the films does not have this much of beautiful pictures unveiling in front of your screen which is again reminds me of the commendable work by Roger Deakins.

Back ground music is another great aspect of this film. It kept edge of the seat every time and added that little sense of suspense to every scene. It is not too much and not barren as well.

Story line is a basic one which does not have a huge amount of depth. So it will not have all the elements at the right place to become an epic . There are no twists and turns in the story and one could imagine what would happen right after 10-15 mins from the start. Director should be able to relate the story in a more cinematographic way. But this is a flat story in a movie perspective.

Acting is average and I cannot stop comparing Tom Hanks in Saving Private Ryan with these new actors. Yes it is bit unfair. But I see that is the bar they have to touch. It is set at a great height but these actors should try to get close to that.

Film is not a treat to watch as it depicts the sorrow, uncertainty and brutality of war. But it rather signifies the sacrifice made by the front line soldiers who are fighting this war. It also invokes the discussion of power struggle in the world which lead to these wars , humans killing humans. We , Humans , are the ones who make our own graves.

title: Brilliant Masterpiece
review: Thank god i'm alive to witness this miracle. it's an epic film from every side, from the cinematography, music, acting, direction by a genius in Sam Mendes. it's one of a kind masterpiece.

title: Astonishing
review: An astonishing cinematographic feat with lifelike production design and evocative score. Though seemingly lacking emotional weight and tension despite particular scenes striving to do so, the exquisite depiction of this heroic story of the wartimes would definitely stand among the best ever made.

title: Great movie.
review: One of the best ww1 movies I've ever watched. Its intense, real, clear and very important you fall in it right after it starts. I would really recomend these movie to anyone who loves history or to anyone who just likes action. The actors are also perfect for the movie and know how to get in the roll. All seems so real like you were a part of it. I was little shocked when one of the main charachters died... I really did not see that comming. But that is actually good, becouse you can see what could really happen. The trenches in the 1st movie part are awasome made too, also the battlefields,... Only thing i would maybe change is that i would add more germans into it, becouse its interesting to watch different uniforms, equipment etc... But generally excellent movie.

review: Honestly,One Shot is really cool, and the lens art is great, but its plot did not impress me deeply. After watching this movie, I only remember that long, well-conceived shot.

Also, the exaggerations in making German's too idiots aren't going well!

Excellent cinematography and background score. Great story telling. Thanks to Late Alfred H. Mendes and the stories that he told to his grandson, we got this gem of a movie. Very touching. Very moving. Made me cry. 5/5 Roger Deakins deserved that Oscar!

I am a poor wayfaring stranger I'm travellin' through this world of woe Yet there's no sickness, toil, nor danger In that bright land to which I go

I'm going there to see my Father I'm going there, no more to roam I'm only going over Jordan I'm only going over home.

title: Good cinematography; okay plot
review: I loved the use of the "one shot" effect; I remember seeing for the first time in Birdman. The cinematography was amazing and credit to Roger Deakins and his crew but the screen play was really lacking in a lot of places. I never really got pulled into the screenplay; I just knew that the protagonist needed to deliver a message. Overall, a good movie but I felt Sam Mendes could've added a little more to it.

title: Technically Brilliant, Flaws Abound
review:
Visually a superb watch. That's what my 7 rating is for. Narrative and plot wise leaves much to be desired.

1. Isn't wireless telegraphy already in use in 1917?

2. Even if there's a need to send a critical written message (to save 1600 lives) by foot as if it's still ancient Mesopotamia - wouldn't one pick much more capable experienced soldiers of the hundreds available to do the job instead of two young uns lounging under a tree?

3. And for 1600 lives wouldn't you send out at least several separate small teams to Ensure at least one would get through?

4. Germans supposed to be planning it for months! Yet for some unexplained absurdity only a few mid-tier generals know about it and at the so very last minute? And these guys and their troops are supposed to have been cut off in No Mans Land and somehow have the means to suddenly discover this major German project but yet can't get a that critical message through except via two scrambling young uns? Come on!

5. Booby trapping the position you leave behind is as old as war gets ... yet two supposedly trained soldiers saunter in gaily without a care?

6. An underground explosion that could bring the structure down would mean near fatality. Even if not, ones eardrums would be a goner. Yet moments later the that same two could be gaily sharing a joke about a rat bitten ear? Huh?

7. And of course that ridiculously miraculous grazing cow and fresh pail of milk out of nowhere, the on-target crash landing plane, all that silly missed shots at close range. Wow! Gadzillions huh??!

8. Frantic frantic message to deliver frantic ... yet you sit down and listen to a lullaby with hundreds of your own troops around without raising a sigh?! Supernova huh?!

More and more huhs?! Go watch it and you'd find at least another dozen more.

It's basically a 2-hour music video suspend your belief visual feast.

title: Amazing camerawork
review: Let me start off by saying that this film in my opinion does not deserve the credit that it gets. It does however very well deserves the cinematography oscar it won, because it was beautifully shot. In my opinion there were some oddities with this film, that's why I don't find it like an 8+. Despite that it was a really interesting film to watch.

title: Fun to see but overrated
review: Technically it's amazing but overall I find it an overrated movie. It's not the first one shot movie and it's not also the best war movie. I know that it's a war movie and like the most of it's genre the objective is to portray war and visually it does it beautifully, but the little plot this have is ridiculous and non-sense in a lot of ways. So they're in war against Germany and they've been probably killing german in the battle field and when they see that a german soilder is going to die on a plain crash they proceed to help him? Really? A soldier that probably killed lots of them comrades and was just minutes ago in a battle with one of they're planes? And that causes one of them to die... Not to mention when in the beginning one of the soldiers got buried by a wall after a grenade explosion and yet he came out of that like it was nothing and only a few dust upon him but that trap in real life would've kill them both but no, dying after trying to help an enemy soldier is more realistic right... And that encounter with the lady with the baby? That really seem forced to me, not to mention that she was surviving with a baby without food and milk and guess what the soldier had? Milk from that stupid cow encounter scene. The scene when he was running and the german were close and shooting at him but yet he didn't got hit was just stupid. The problem of this was that they thought that just because the visuals were amazing they could give us any kind of non-sense plot and it would be cool, well, that doesn't work with me.

title: An exceptional experience
review:
"1917" is a poignant film which tells a story inspired by real facts during the First World War. That makes the film more real and more sensational. I was impressed by the way that the main actors play. It was like we were in the film, we were with the characters and we could feel their feelings, their stress. I appreciated the film very much. I want to thank Sam Mendes for directing and writing the script. It gave us the impression that the film was shot in one shot thanks to the sequence plan. It totally immersed us in the atmosphere of the First World War.
Furthermore, the landscape of death and desolation puts forward the butchery of the war. I like the goal of the film. The issue of saving lives is more important than the main characters, hence the title of the film "1917".That highlights the impressive number of soldiers who fought in the war.
I think everyone should see the film. It reinforces our knowledge about the war. We are completely in the action, we want the mission to be accomplished.
This a great film! Take time for yourself and go watch the amazing film and enjoy !

review:
I saw the moivir entitled 1917 last week because my school forced me to see it but it was better than i imagined.1917 is a british epic war film which was Realised on 15 january 2020

They must cross a no man's land.however it was hopeless to do that.But this is a film and they go send a message to english troops where blakés brother was a soldier (one of the two heroes).this trip is very stressful ,the two guys are often in danger ans (spoiler) even blake dies while trying to help a soldier.i recommend this film but it was some flaws like they mange to get out of a very delicate situation like in a video game and ,in deed this is why i don't rate the film 10/10 .despite that, the film is nice for some childs/teenager ans people.

title: Beautiful and sobering
review: A movie that will no doubt go down on a lot of best lists. It it beautiful, intense, and depressing all within two hours.

title: 103 Years Ago..Is Now Today.
review:
I am grateful that one of my Grandma's friends recommended that we see 1917. All I knew about the movie was that it was a war movie, it has lots of critical praise, and that it was nominated for Best Picture. After seeing the movie, let me tell you that all this hype is well earned.

While 1917 is set in World War 1, it reminded me of a classic World War 2 movie-Saving Private Ryan. Both films are about the horrors of war and a dangerous mission to find the brother of another soldier. 1917 has another plot point as well though, where 2 soldiers are going to enemy territory to offer peace and stop a battle that will have deadly results if pursued.

1917 succeeds most with the emotion, and that's what carries most of the movie. For example, one of the 2 soldiers is stabbed and then dies in the other's arms before he can get proper help. This is very emotional, especially since the viewer can connect with the bond that they have. Any death, whether from an enemy or not, is felt by the viewer.

Speaking of the deaths, the violence is very effective as is necessary, of course. I especially appreciated that the gore was shown but not as graphic as Saving Private Ryan. Simply put, it shows enough war violence to stun the audience but not be too depressing.

1917 is also effective with jump scares. Yes, there are jump scares, but not in a lame horror-film way. These are jump scares done right and well deserved. A character may be walking around and then without warning...BOOM! A gun is shot or a grenade is thrown.

The movie also has great cinematography, as other reviewers have said-this should be considered to be among the best camera work of any film this year.

Another great film-making aspect is that it has a "one shot" feel that makes the movie look to have one continuous shot, not broken up into different angles(The Oscar winner Birdman was filmed this way as well).

1917 also does a great job of taking us to the year. That is, it really feels like it's 1917 now, even though it was 103 years ago.

While I have not seen any other of the nominees for Best Picture, I agree that this deserved one. I have minor flaws with it, but they don't affect the movie's overall high quality.

This ranks with American Beauty, Road To Perdition, and Revolutionary Road as one of Sam Mendes's best movies, and is well worth the time to see, so please do so!

Note: After the movie ended, I asked my Grandma what she would rate it, and she said a 9.5 or a 10. I was shocked, as she hardly ever gives 10s. This got me asking what other movies she would rate a 10, to which she listed Hidden Figures, My Fair Lady, Titanic, Mary Poppins, among others.

Since this is the case, that is 2 10/10s for you to base your decision on to see this movie. I hope you choose to see it, 1917 is a rewarding experience!

*If you enjoyed this review, please click on cinephile-27690 for more. Movies are my passion so allow me to share it with you. I know I am a bit amateurish, but I hope I am improving over time! Thank you for reading this and any other review!

title: A must watch
review:
A must watch for fans of great movies.
Don't miss this one.

title: A great action movie, a terrible drama.
review:
Firstly, I want to say that I went to the cinema for an English lesson, so I wasn't that hyped but I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of the film. Ranked first come action scenes that are really impressive, hook the spectator immediately and are actually stressful. Then, the OST was really goof and perfect. Another great achievement, the set : I think about the burning city where Schofield got chased in particular. Finally, the shooting method that makes it look like an entire sequence shot and the actors' gmae which is not the best but really satisfying make it a great movie.
Now, let's talk about negative aspect. This film didn't make me feel sad, happy or whatever (except a bit stressed), we can't deny a lack of emotion, it is not emotionless but almost (due to a lack of character development : we don't know them much nor how close they are,...). Then a major negative point is that we don't fell war horror and futility, something essential in a war film ; they don't insist on all the soldiers that died for nothing, and that mixed with a happy-ending makes it look like war was easy or nothing.
Overall, this film is great for an action film but takes away the dramatic aspect of war, which is a really important in that type of film ; great entertainment but not the film of the year.

title: Mind Boggling Technological Achievement
review: Sam Mendez directed this visually extravagant drama about two young British soldiers on a perilous mission in World War 1. The idea behind the camerawork is meant to be to bring viewers close to the action, which is unique and amazing; this adds a bonus to the film: we feel more included, just as if we were with the soldiers in the trenches, a very realistic seeking type of filming. « 1917 » is certainly a technical marvel, with its brilliant sound work, visual effects, and Lee Smith's editing. The least I can say is that Sam Mendes nailed it. But, the only critique I can say is that we never really know the main characters well, making it difficult to be invested in their ultimate fate and I was waiting for a happy ending which I didn't get. Nevertheless this movie stands as a feat one, making it top 5 on my favorite movies this last year. Great job Sam Mendes, war has never been captured so incredibly.

title: 1917- So much potential...?
review:
With director Sam Mendes inspired by his own grandfather, this deeply personal story had fantastic potential to be the next Great War epic.
The writing and filming techniques are very ambitious; they clearly make you feel like you are there, seeing the scenes through the characters eyes. While the cinematographic aspects of this are interesting, it sometimes feels like they focus on this too much, which meant the character development is somewhat weak. We never really get to know the main characters well, making it difficult to be invested in their ultimate fate. It is likely this was an intentional move from Mendes to illustrate the famous British 'stiff upper lip', but it is a little clumsy in its execution. It is important to mention the ending; this film absolutely has you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end, and while it should have been a satisfying ending, with the characters succeeding in their mission, it leaves you feeling slightly defeated. The way the film illustrates the terrible waste of life, taking you right to the heart of the trenches and ultimately knowing that despite this short respite, nearly 10 million military personal died during WW1 really hits home.

title: Emotion throughout the whole film
review:
It's a masterpiece. A rare film that will make you emotional you will get in the character skin.
It feels like playing a game.
Those feelings I got with the charge of rohan in the white city, I got here too.

title: Very good movie, very good director
review: This film is brilliant, extraordinary , moving... I think you get it, I loved that movie. Throughout the film we could see special effects such as the crash of German plane. All these effects and all the scenes were extremely well filmed. The director managed to make this film very dynamic without reminding us of the long history of the war. We followed the two soldiers on their grueling mission, which cost one of them his life... It was a very emotional moment beacause he died trying to save a German soldier from the flames. I think anyone would have been moved by that scene. Also, the last scene of the film is really touching. In this film, Shaw Mendes showed us that in spite of the war and these disastrous conditious of living there was a form of hope and humanity. Nevertheless, I find that the director did not put much emphasis on the war in general. It was not at all extended in time and we hust saw a few days of these difficult moments. That is my only regret. After seeing this film I understand very well why it received a prestigious award at ta ceremony that took place this weekend in London. I was thrilled to see this film and to see the heroic deed these two soldiers performed.

title: BEYOND CINEMA
review: 1917 is one of those very few films that give you a one-in-a-million experience. The continuous shot really anchors your senses to the screen as you follow the journey of these two young men. The cinematography, lighting, production design, blocking, and acting are all FLAWLESS. Each scene delivers its own unique composition and emotion that you just can't help but appreciate the vision and treatment that this film was so tenderly given. DEFINITELY A MUST WATCH! DON'T WATCH IT ANYWHERE ELSE UNLESS IT'S ON THE BIG SCREEN. IT TRULY TAKES THE MEANING OF 'CINEMATIC EXPERIENCE' TO A WHOLE 'NOTHER DAMN LEVEL!

title: Best WW1 movie I've seen in a LONG time!
review:
Personally, I've always wanted a First world war movie with a budget of more than a indie project, and 1917 fulfilled this role, and more.
Spoiler Alert! You've been warned!
1. The Plot: It's simple. Two soldiers are tasked with delivering an urgent message or 1600 men (Along with one of the twos's brother) will fall into a german trap and die. The way it goes about this is what stunned me. One second your telling a funny story, the next your holding your dead friend. It never bogs down, even in the slower parts, and keeps you on the edge of your seat the entire time. One minor problem I have, is that they could develop the characters a little more, but that doesn't matter much.
2. The cinematography: It is amazing, like everyone else says. The 'one continuous shot" thing actually works, and I could only count one time where they made a cut. There were also scenes that genuinely took my breath away. The Town being lit up by flares (for example) is easily the best cinematography I've ever seen, and one of the best scenes of the entire decade.
Conclusion: One of the best movies of the year, and sure contender for best picture 1917 is an incredible, gritty joy ride but is ever so slightly bogged down by less character development.
9.6/10

title: Masterpiece
review: Something that everyone needs to see. Probably the only way to avoid all this pain and sadness the war can cause. One of the best and heart touching movies ever.

title: I FELT AS IF I HAD BEEN DRAGGED THROUGH BARBED WIRE
review:
Wow! The camera work, the sets, the cinematography. Unreal because it was so real. You feel as though you are part of this epic the entire way through.

I felt a little overcome at times but then I guess this heightened the sense of being in the action.

Loved that the director didn't overplay the heroism or the horror or the pathos. Just in your face realism. Obviously there was a lot of over the top action and plot twists, it is a movie. But, what a movie!

A must, must see!!!

title: Great music
review: Music is doing whole film. It's holding in tension and shows us what to expect or what not to expect. It's good film.

title: It's so good...
review: This is one of the best ww one movies arround, very good picture shots.

title: We finish where we start.
review:
1917 is a film with a very well achieved use of a long shot, which has an intention to the message of the film. The film represents a cyclical process of the characters. In the opening shot the characters start on the floor, resting. This first shot is a static one of a grass and some flowers and we begin to back off, this means that what allows us to rest will be moving away more and more from us. Or worse, we are the ones who move away from that.

That last idea expresses the disagreement against the war that the film (and every good war movie has) communicates. This is indicated with false conformism in all soldiers along the way. From the ironic names of the trenches, to the attitude of the captain before leaving the trenches.

The film generates empathy by including a human purpose to the war, such as avoiding the death of a brother and saving many men who will unnecessarily go to fight. The purpose of the long one shot is to generate that trip that seems to have no return. Then, we realize that it does have an end. The surviving character ends as he starts resting in a tree. Of course, the difference is that now he is alone and that is the difference between the beginning and the end of both the film and the war.

An important and symmetrical element during the film are the flowers seen at the beginning, these appear in moments of calm, in the most sacred moments taken from the war situation. The flowers can be seen at the beginning, when a character dies and finally at the end of the movie, representing that the character returned to that place where he can rest.

title: Great movie!
review: I loved the cinematic filming and realism of the movie. The movie seemed to portray the War scene in relation to two mens experience in real time differently than any other war movie I have watched. I wish I could have seen more of the backstories related to the characters, but overall I really enjoyed it!

title: Great experience
review: To be honest I am not the biggest war movies fan. Gone to the movie way too late with all awards in mind. So I can't say that I didn't have high expectations. But it blew me away. They say the movie is shot to look like a continuous take. And it does. For the first half of the movie I was just trying to spot where are the cuts. But eventually just gave up and enjoyed the ride. The cinematography is exceptional! Felt like most of war movies are too slow or feels too long therefore boring. It was nothing like that. The action, the score, the sound, the gritty realism of it all kept me on the edge of the seat. It didn't feel like a two hour movie for me. Though there is not much of a story but I didn't mind that at all. There is a mission that needs to be done and problems and struggles characters end up dealing with keeps the movie going. Didn't mind that characters weren't too interesting either. These are people in the middle of the war. So every little detail we get to know about the characters feels compelling. The acting of course is excellent. Very little criticism overall. Besides that it is not that historically accurate.

title: Overall, good movie. Just don't expect anything unexpected.
review:
I went to see "1917" tonight as a sure way to cheer me up. Indeed, what better way to put a string of bad days into perspective than a WWI story! The Spanish flu - admittedly worse than COVID-19, as far as we know it - did not even need to be covered, since it broke out one year later and 1917 was horrendous enough in its own right.
